botanical_details.genus: Solanum can be annuals, perennials, evergreen or deciduous shrubs or twining climbers, with simple or pinnnately lobed leaves and star- or bowl-shaped, 5-lobed flowers with prominent stamens, followed by fleshy fruits

how_to_grow.cultivation: Prefers well-drained soil, high in organic matter that is consistenly moist to prevent blossom end rot and to provide roots with the ability to better absorb nutrients. Mulching around the plant witll help with moisture retention. Transplant the matured pot-grown plant into the outside ground two weeks after the last frost. Cover the main stem with up to 2 inches of topsoil to promote root development for better support against the wind. Provide 8 hours of full sun for the best flavour. Caging or trellising is recommended to allow the plant to grow vertically which will promote a higher crop yield and give space for a larger number of plants.
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by seed six weeks before the last forecast for frost.
how_to_grow.pruning: Remove yellowing lower leaves as the plant grows to allow the plant to focus on fruiting.
how_to_grow.pests: May be susceptible to Tomato hornworm.
how_to_grow.diseases: May be susceptible to Tobacco mosaic and wilts. Remove any infected leaves immediately.
